div3.head: Battalion of Cavalry.
div3.p:
--In the month of February I received authority from the Secretary of War to raise a Battalion or Regiment of Cavalry.
I have hesitated to undertake to do so until this time, and I now propose to raise a Battalion of Cavalry.

Persons desiring to unit with me in this patriotic effort, and those wishing authority to recruit and raise companies, will address me at this place, or what is still better, report in person at once.
I expect to have two companies of infantry and one of artillery attached to my command.
Call at the office of the Battalion, Main street, Richmond, Va., opposite the office of the Southern Express Company.

Capt. Comd'g Cavalry Co.,

div3.head: Wise Zouaves.
div3.p:
The undersigned is enlisting a company of infantry for the 20th Regiment Virginia Volunteers, to be called the Wise Zouaves, in compliment of the memory of the late Captain Wise.
This company will be instructed by Mr. C. F. Pardigon in the Zouave drill of the French Infantry, and taught by him the bayonet exercise.
Being familiar in all its detail, and having aided Captain Car in the translation of the French works on Bayonet Exercise, his ability to instruct in that drill cannot be questioned.

Militiamen desiring to enter this service will apply to the undersigned, on 12th street, one door above Main.
The usual bounty of $50 will be paid the men when mustered into the Confederate service.

div3.head: Maryland Battalion.
div3.p: The undersigned has been authorized to organize a Battalion of Infantry, to form part of the Maryland Line.

Under an act of Congress, approved February 15, 1862, any native or adopted citizen of Maryland may, upon his own application, be transferred at once to the Maryland, Line.
Or any company composed of citizens of Maryland or the District of Columbia may, upon application, be so transferred.
Individuals or companies desirous of joining this Battalion, will apply in person at the office of Weston & Williams, No. 16 Pearl street, or by mail to

div3.p:
This Department is Desirous of purchasing arms from those parties having good double-barrel shot guns, sporting rifles, or any kind of weapons that will be useful in the field.
These arms will be fairly appraised on their delivery in Richmond, and payments will be promptly made.
Agents heretofore collecting state arms for this Department are requested to collect and forward these private arms as promptly as possible.

div3.head:
Heavy Artillery.
$50 bounty, and
uniforms furnished.
div3.p:
The undersigned are authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Company for the heavy Artillery service.
We have been for the past eleven months in active service as Lieutenants of such a company, and have already a number of men enlisted.
All who desire to join us will please apply at our recruiting office, No. 17, Main street, up stairs, to Wm. Lawson, Company H, First Regiment Virginia Volunteers; or at our Camp in Yorktown.
I have been authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Regiment of Heavy Artillery for three years, or the war.

This regiment is rapidly filling up, and wants only a few companies requisite to its completion.
I should be glad to Confed with contains who have companies, and also with those who desire to raise companies.

"Volunteers or recruits enlisting for three years, or the war, will receive a bounty of $50, payable as soon as they are swore into service and accepted, upon inspection by a medical officer, together with transportation, and subsistence from the time and place of enlistment, until inspected and mustered."

Twelve months men can re-enlist singly or by companies for two years or the war, and receive $50 bounty; and will also be transferred during the twenty days previous to the expiration of their present term.
Volunteers will be received singly or by companies from any portion of the Confederacy.
Office--Tenth street, three doors from Main City Post-Office, Box 877.

div3.head: Deserted
div3.p:
--From my company, at Camp Winder, on Saturday, April 5th, Christopher Brune.
Said Brune is about 30 years of age, 5 feet 8 inches high, auburn hair, brown eyes, and by profession a ship carpenter.
He wore, when he left camp, dark blue coat and pants, grey fatigue cap, with yellow band.
John Herbig,
Captain Infirmary Company.
All members of my company who are now at large in this city will promptly report at my rendezvous in five days from date, or be considered as deserters.
